casebody.data:
Wainwright and others v. Harper. In cases of judgements by default, the statute of jeofails does not apply to cure errors and defects in the proceedings. In such cases, the writ is part of the record; and writ being in assumpsit and declaration in covenant, the variance is fatal. Upon a supersedeas to a judgement recovered in the circuit court of Dinwiddie by Harper the defendant in error, against the plaintiffs in error, Wainwright, Allgood and Grammer, it appeared that the writ was in assumpsit, and *271the declaration in covenant; and the judgement was by default, for want of appearance. Allison, for plaintiffs in error.

In cases of judgements by default for want of appearance, the writ, and the indorsement on it, are necessarily part of the record; Nadenbush v. Lane, 4 Rand. 413. It is now settled, that the statute of jeofails does not apply to cases of judgement by default; Payne v. Britton, 6 Rand. 102. The variance between the writ and the declaration in this case, is fatal; Ming & al. v. Gwatkin, Id. 551.

Per curiam.

The judgement must be reversed.
